style.palette: muted WWII tones + bright highlight colors
style.characters: simple flat shapes with expressive eyes
style.motion: snappy, minimal tweening, UI-like overlays for tech parts

scenes.title: Before Enigma — Simple Secrets
scenes.narration: Before the Enigma, armies sent messages by runners, flags, or plain radio. Codes were simple, so enemies could often guess them.

visuals.camera: wide shot of a paper map; arrows move across; radio tower emits waves
actions: Soldier whispers a simple code to a runner
Enemy with headphones scribbles translation easily

scenes.title: Enter Enigma — A Magic Letter Mixer
scenes.narration: Germany adopted the Enigma: a machine that turns each letter into a different letter, changing every key press.

visuals.camera: close-up of a cute, boxy machine with keys and light bulbs
actions: Finger presses A; lamp for Q lights
Press A again; a different lamp, T, lights

scenes.title: Enigma Construction — What’s Inside
scenes.narration: An Enigma has a keyboard and lampboard, a plugboard in front, several rotors in the middle, and a reflector in the back. Wires inside map letters to other letters.

actions: Labels pop in: Keyboard, Lampboard, Plugboard, Rotors, Reflector
Wires draw between letters to show remapping
on_screen_text: Keyboard → Plugboard → Rotors → Reflector → Rotors → Plugboard → Lamps
Symmetric encryption: same settings encrypt & decrypt

callouts.note: Each rotor permutes A–Z; they rotate
Sends signal back a different way

scenes.title: Rotors and the Marching Alphabet
scenes.narration: Rotors step like an odometer. The right rotor steps every press. At special notches, the middle rotor also steps, causing occasional double-steps.

visuals.camera: side view of three rotors: Right, Middle, Left
actions: Counter wheels marked A–Z rotate
At notch, middle rotor advances; show 'double-step' moment

scenes.title: Daily Settings — The Secret Recipe
scenes.narration: Operators shared a daily key: which rotors to use and in what order, each ring setting, the starting positions, and which plugboard pairs to connect.

actions: Paper key sheet appears: Rotor order = III II I
Ring settings = 02 18 12 (example)
Start = A Q L
Plugboard pairs: A–M, T–Z, etc.

scenes.title: How a Letter Travels
scenes.narration: Type a letter: it goes through the plugboard, rotors, hits the reflector, and returns through the rotors and plugboard to light a lamp. Then the right rotor steps.

actions: Signal draws along path with arrows
Reflects and returns; different lamp lights
Rotor advances one step
on_screen_text: Path: PB → R1 → R2 → R3 → Reflector → R3 → R2 → R1 → PB

scenes.title: Why It Seemed Unbreakable
scenes.narration: With many rotors, ring settings, start positions, and plugboard cables, there were astronomically many possibilities. Guessing by hand was hopeless.

visuals.camera: numbers raining down Matrix-style but playful
actions: Counter spins up to huge combinations
Enemy analyst faints comically

scenes.title: During the War — Messages in the Air
scenes.narration: German units used Enigma on land, sea, and air. Radio carried scrambled text, which looked like nonsense to everyone else.

visuals.camera: montage: tank, U-boat, aircraft; radio waves between them
actions: Operators type; ciphertext prints: XQYJZ...
Allies listen but cannot read

scenes.title: Cracking Enigma — Team Effort
scenes.narration: Polish mathematicians made early breakthroughs. Later at Bletchley Park, codebreakers like Alan Turing and Gordon Welchman built 'bombes' to test settings quickly, using clues called 'cribs.'

actions: Cartoon portraits labeled: Rejewski, Różycki, Zygalski
Cut to Turing and Welchman beside a spinning bombe machine
Crib overlay: 'WEATHER REPORT' aligns with ciphertext

scenes.title: Why Breaking It Mattered
scenes.narration: Reading Enigma let the Allies reroute ships, anticipate attacks, and plan operations. Many historians believe this shortened the war and saved countless lives.

visuals.camera: map of Atlantic; convoy path bends safely away from U-boats
actions: Enemy plan pops up; Allied path adjusts
Calendar flips faster

scenes.title: After Enigma — Lessons for Today
scenes.narration: Enigma showed that strong math and careful procedures matter. Modern cryptography uses computers and public-key methods, but the idea of well-designed secrets remains.

visuals.camera: Enigma morphs into a modern lock icon and a laptop
actions: Binary digits flow into a padlock that clicks shut

scenes.title: Quick Recap
scenes.narration: Enigma mixed letters using plugs, rotors, and a reflector. Daily settings kept it synced. Codebreakers used math and machines to read messages, changing the course of WWII.

visuals.camera: icon parade: plugboard → rotors → reflector → bombe → convoy
actions: Checkmarks appear over each icon

deeper_dive_cards.title: Plugboard (Steckerbrett)
deeper_dive_cards.content: Up to 10 letter pairs typically connected. Each pair swaps letters both before and after the rotor path, dramatically increasing complexity.

deeper_dive_cards.title: Rotors
deeper_dive_cards.content: Each rotor is a 26-letter substitution with a turnover notch. Common rotors: I, II, III, IV, V; later naval versions added more. Ring setting offsets the wiring map relative to the turnover notch.

deeper_dive_cards.title: Reflector (Umkehrwalze)
deeper_dive_cards.content: Creates a reversible path: encryption and decryption are identical with the same settings. Downside: a letter can never encrypt to itself, a property used by codebreakers.

deeper_dive_cards.title: Double-Step Phenomenon
deeper_dive_cards.content: When the middle rotor advances on its own and again due to the right rotor’s notch, causing two steps in a row. This affects the cipher’s periodicity.

deeper_dive_cards.title: Bombe Logic (Simplified)
deeper_dive_cards.content: Bombes tested many rotor positions for contradictions using guessed plaintext fragments. When no contradictions arose, likely settings were flagged for operators to try.
